Reviews.Title: Motorola Droid 2 A955
Reviews.Author: LadyofLakeSeminole
Reviews.Content: This is my first smartphone up grading from a Razor I've had for a few years,and I have been very pleased.  It does work wonderful with the Pageplus service, which is why I brought it.(No costly contracts) I also like the keyboard, enough room between letters not to hit two. The battery holds up well for me, I charge every couple of days. The delivery was quick and on time, it appeared to be a new phone as the ad stated. Overall this was a good purchase and a good experience.

Reviews.Title: Very satisfied customer
Reviews.Author: Susan Clopton
Reviews.Content: I bought this Motorola Droid 2 from Ross Cellular new and it appeared to be so. First off I want to say excellent cutomer service. I had a battery issue but didnt want to return the phone and I relayed this to Ross and the company sent me out a new one along with a new battery charger and a MicroSD card within two days. That was cool. This is really my first smart phone and I am quite pleased with it. I am using it with Page Plus and it works great with the 1200 Talk and Text plan with 100mg of data. Whenever I need the data I am able to turn it on and off easily. The only negative thing is the camera only focus's in macro but after getting on the Android sites this is a software problem I know I can solve. This phone gets updates OTA. I already been updated twice for the Android version. I highly recommend Ross for their excellent customer service and I do recommend the Droid 2 for the price and the ease of using this phone. I'd also recommend splurging for a few accessories like the docking station and the super car charger you can get off amazon.

Reviews.Title: It will betray you.
Reviews.Author: Self
Reviews.Content: I bought this hoping for a cheap, minimal smartphone.  What I got instead:-- a phone that appears to turn off its own ringer (a single-swipe operation when the phone is locked)-- a phone whose screen has accumulated microabrasions that now look like glaucoma-- a phone whose microphone abruptly stopped working (apparently an internal grommet is dislodged into the air canal)-- a phone whose "alarm" functionality is unbelievably bad:  the alarm unlocks the phone, then your first touch of the phone (e.g. to take it out of your pocket) puts the alarm on snooze and takes it off your screenThis phone is the worst of both worlds:  not simple enough to operate reliably without studying the manual, and not powerful enough to be worth studying.

Fast forward a week.  it does this more often.  Not responding to my presses, clicking things at random, calling, etc.  It took a lot more locking/unlocking to get it back to normal.  fast forward another week, and it's now a paperweight.  Literally every time I unlock it, it goes "berserk" if you will.  I tried bringing it to the Verizon store, but they said all the phones did this, and that it was a tech problem, and that I was stuck with it.Now, it's all I can do not to throw this junk out the window, it's so frustrating.  When it works, it was alright, which is almost never.Don't waste your money.

Reviews.Title: Purchased for my page plus plan
Reviews.Author: J. Arsenault
Reviews.Content: Registering the phone with page plus cellular was very easy (I had worried, needlessly, that it wouldn't be compatible).  Unlike some sellers mentioned in other reviews, Oakland Wireless did NOT include a memory card in the phone.  Never having had a phone that accepted memory cards and not realizing the SD card wasn't in the list of included accessories, it took a while, with no help from Oakland wireless (but they did respond quickly to me emails asking for help), to figure this out.  The pictures on how to insert the card were clear but it wasn't obvious to me what the SD card looked like installed). Installing/removing it is easy. I downloaded the manual from Motorola but mostly haven't used it.  Maybe reading it would allow me to move some of the icons to other 'pages' of my screen and/or remove some I would never use.  I can only reposition them within the same visual portion of the page.  At this time I'm not using it for internet access (but bought the phone should I one day want to).  The camera quality is pretty poor - 6 pixels, as I recall, isn't sufficient for a decent picture.  I don't use the keyboard because the logical one, with the camera turned sideways, has been fine (but the tiny keyboard is not fine at all for my fingers).  The phone arrived very quickly; probably at the beinning of the arrival timeframe, in fine condition.  It's heavier than some of my friends' phones; that's probably due to the keyboard.  Sound quality is ok. I don't use it often and keep it in sleep mode most of the time. It holds a charge for about 2-3 weeks.UPDATE JULY 2013: After several months, I find the phone ok, nothing special.  The scrolling on the touch screen is 'too fast' for my klutzy fingers.  BUT the biggest problem with the phone - I am on a prepaid plan (I pay for each minute):  It is VERY difficult to end the call, and I often pay for an extra minute of time.  I have pressed the end-call button, held it down, pressed multiple times, contemplated throwing the phone against a nearby wall, and have even exited that screen to put the phone into sleep mode (effective but a big pain).  Ending the call is a capricious enterprise. Also, turning the phone on and off is a bit difficult - the button is small and seems recessed.2nd UPDATE Nov 2013.  I seldom use the phone.  Last week the battery stopped holding a charge and would only charge to 60%.  A battery store person said that because it would only charge to 60% the problem isn't in the battery. The phone's charge did hit 0% charge at least once (lack of use and interest). I'll be ordering a new battery just to be sure (if turns out ok, it will be a backup), I've purchased a different phone as I'm heading out of town in 2 days and need it for the trip. I did prefer the touch screen to the keyboard after a while.

Reviews.Title: Works with Page Plus "out of the box"
Reviews.Author: J. P. GRANT
Reviews.Content: I'm new to the world of smart phones, and I wanted an inexpensive way (cost about $135 at Amazon) to see if I even wanted to have one. And whether I could get by without a $100 monthly bill. Where I live only the Verizon system offers decent service. I didn't realize it, but you need to figure on buying a micro SDHC card, or this phone is pretty useless - like no camera function. Added about $28 to the cost for 32 gigs.So why do I give it only a 3? It works right away and that's a big plus. As a phone, it won't download my contacts to my 2013 Lexus, and the bluetooth connection keeps flipping on and off. But it has never cut off while I was talking. For very brief intervals I am unable to initiate a call or receive one. The manual is a .pdf only, and that is often not much help. The manual itself doesn't seem to describe my phone and its functions, it's more like it's for a series of phones and often not for mine. The Android manual for this software version is equally general but sometimes helpful. The phone keeps asking me which "switch off" option I want to select, and I have to keep pressing the "go back one step" icon to not switch off. Stays on when it's connected to the car. It's very unstable in Google Maps, and won't let me enter a destination with the onscreen keyboard. But the pull out physical keyboard does better.Page Plus (PP) service has been excellent and very inexpensive compared to Verizon. It's hard to figure out how to set up their service, but they have a reseller called Kitty Wireless which is fantastic. They walk you through the whole intricate process online. PP offers only prepaid service, but you can set it up with automatic renewals through Kitty that let's you dispense with the need to buy PIN cards each month. So it seems like a contract service, with the plus that you can't unknowingly run over your plan limits and can also terminate anytime.I am still learning the phone, so maybe I'll like it better in time. Otherwise, I'll wait till a later model phone is available at a reasonable price, and that works with PP.

Reviews.Title: Great Phone, Great Price, Charger Issues
Reviews.Author: Judith
Reviews.Content: Bought this phone to replace my HTC Evo Shift with Sprint.  Never could get reception with Sprint and was paying a fortune, plus the phone software and updates caused repeated problems and cost me $99 a month.  Now I get reception, switched my 32GB sd microcard to the new phone, used backup pro app to save and then restore it everything without problem onto the new phone, set up Pageplus for $29.99 per month, ported my number in 3 hrs via Pageplus (you need your "passcode" from your current carrier which I discovered well hidden in my online Sprint acct access, so get it before you start the porting) and am good to go, get reception and saving hundreds per year.  Phone comes without (at least mine) a micro SD card (I had extras so no worries) and with an electronic charger.  You do not need to buy extras as my car and extra phone chargers from other brands work fine with it.  I like the weight and keyboard is an easier interface than the Evo.  Took me a few minutes to get used to the HTC vs. Motorola quirks, but all good in about 8 hrs total.This phone worked well until a few months ago when it refused to charge in my car.  Now the charger only works now and again.  Looks like just a matter of time until I will need to purchase a new one as it's now happy charging via the wall either.
